awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Collaborative Research: An Experimentally Validated Simulation Framework for Next-Generation Plastic Optical Fiber-based Systems on Airplanes
awd_abstract_narration:
GOALI: Collaborative Research: An Experimentally-Validated Simulation Framework for Next-Generation Plastic Optical Fiber-based Systems on Airplanes

This research project seeks to develop an experimentally-validated simulation framework that will help investigate and design Plastic Optical Fiber (POF)-based communication systems and networks for airplanes. The main participants are The College of Staten Island (CSI/CUNY), Montana State University-Bozeman (MSU), and The City College of New York (CCNY/CUNY). It will also involve an international collaboration with the University of Zaragoza (UZ), Spain, and a GOALI component with the world-leader in avionics, The Boeing Co. Avionic communication systems are currently undergoing a radical transformation in both the commercial and military sectors. The former (commercial), the focus of this project, exhibits an increasing need for high-speed communication due to emerging applications for the traveling public, as well as higher operational needs for the ultra-modern aircraft that are being deployed. In addition, aging aircraft wiring poses a significant threat to aircrafts, as electrical wires have proven to be one of the major factors leading to airplane failures. Therefore, there is an ongoing migration of avionic data buses from copper to fiber-based networks, since the latter exhibit high transmission capacity and high electromagnetic immunity. The investigators have suggested POF as a suitable transmission medium for next-generation avionic communication systems on commercial aircrafts due to its ease of handling, light weight and high tolerance to vibration, among other benefits. While experimental results have demonstrated the feasibility of high-speed data transmission over different types of POFs, the modeling and simulation of POF-based systems is lagging behind. Therefore, the investigators will develop a comprehensive set of components and simulation techniques that empower engineers to systematically explore different designs before settling on a final custom solution for their particular system. They will also make a special effort to involve women and underrepresented groups in the effort since they traditionally are not exposed to avionic systems engineering.  

The goal of the project is to study the use of POF in an airplane environment with an emphasis on system performance and high bit rate transmissions. Glass fiber has a number of problems when used as a transmission medium in short-reach networks such as avionic networks. It is mechanically weak and generally lacks bending ability. Also, the core diameter of single-mode glass optical fiber is small (~10mm) and it requires very precise handling techniques. Plastic optical fiber (POF), even with its high loss (~100-300 dB/km) and diffusion, can solve these problems since it is easier to handle and has a bending radius of about 5 mm, which can be a big benefit in avionics networks. Its larger core diameter (50 mm to 1 mm) enables easy connections using inexpensive connectors. The increased core diameter allows higher tolerance to vibrations and to dust particles that can totally obstruct light propagation in glass fibers. The investigators will cover three different types of POF: large-core (up to 1 mm) step-index plastic optical fiber (SI-POF), multicore step-index plastic optical fiber (MC SI-POF), and graded-index plastic optical fiber (GI-POF). There are existing simulation models that capture all the guided modes in multimode fibers with detailed spatial fields; however, they are not adequate for large-core fibers, where there are millions of propagation modes. The project intends to develop computationally-efficient models that circumvent the need for prohibitively long simulation times and excessive computer memory. The model validation, a critical component of the project, will be done via a combination of the state-of-the-art device characterization laboratory at the University of Zaragoza and a testbed at the College of Staten Island. Montana State University will primarily work on advanced modulation formats and digital signal processing algorithms. Boeing Co. will provide prototype devices and realistic system designs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Data traffic in contemporary passenger planes has been continuously increasing, both in the cockpit and the passenger cabin. To satisfy these traffic demands, aircraft manufacturers and airlines are interested in the deployment of optical fibers on commercial aircraft. Among other applications, optical fibers enable high-bandwidth inflight entertainment (IFE) in the passenger cabin, including on-demand movies and TV, as well as high-speed internet access, games, shopping, and so forth.

New aircraft models, such as the Airbus A380 and Boeing 787, already feature fiber-optic networks. However, older commercial aircraft are still equipped with copper wires which will not be able to support future high-bandwidth communications services. It is envisioned that, gradually, the cabling infrastructure in these aircraft will be replaced by optical fibers as well, in order to become future-proof.

Computer-aided design (CAD) of the physical layer of avionic fiber-optic networks is still in its infancy. To enable the performance comparison of different optical network topologies inside a plane, it is necessary to build a simulation framework with a library of models of key optical, opto-electronic, and electronic avionics communications components. For ease of use, these models should be represented visually as interconnected blocks in a schematic within a graphic user interface (GUI). The user can alter the network architecture and vary the physical parameters of individual modules withing certain ranges without extensive programming knowledge.

The purpose of this research project was the development of a simulation framework for the design of optical fiber networks for civil aviation. The main goal of this project was to develop a complete set of simulation modules that will allow communications engineers to design next-generation avionics networks based on a variety of optical fibers, such as plastic or glass multimode and few-mode fibers and glass single-mode fibers.

This research project was mainly a collaboration among the College of Staten Island (CSI) and The City College of New York (CCNY) at The City University of New York (CUNY), and Montana State University-Bozeman (MSU).

In the context of this project, the Optical Communications Group at MSU develop a set of simulation modules on the following topics:

  • Spectrally-efficient modulation formats, such as M-ary pulse amplitude modulation (PAM), for avionics optical networks using different types of optical fibers and direct-detection.
  • Conventional digital signal processing (DSP) algorithms for direct-detection M-PAM receivers, e.g., feed-forward equalizers (FFEs) and decision feedback equalizer (DFEs) for the compensation of intersymbol interference due to modal dispersion in multimode optical fibers.
  • Machine learning algorithms, e.g., various neural network architectures, for improving the performance of conventional blind adaptive equalizers.
  • Energy- and spectrally-efficient modulation formats, amenable to direct-detection, for propagation over either single-mode fibers inside the aircraft or for free-space optical communication between aircraft, satellites and aircraft, and aircraft and ground stations. In particular, M-ary differential phase shift keying (DPSK) with multisymbol, maximum-likelihood interferometric receivers, and M-ary Stokes vector modulation (SVM) with maximum-likelihood polarimetric receivers were studied in depth.

As a side activity, MSU studied new techniques for the characterization of modal effects in few-mode fibers.

Scientific merit

 Avionics: The project advanced the computer-aided design (CAD) of the physical layer of avionic fiber-optic networks. In addition, MSU  studied, for the first-time, M-ary differential phase shift keying (DPSK) with multisymbol, maximum-likelihood interferometric receivers, and M-ary Stokes vector modulation (SVM) with maximum-likelihood polarimetric receivers for high-capacity free-space optical links between aircraft, satellites and aircraft, and aircraft and ground stations. Finally, MSU studied new techniques for the characterization of modal effects in few-mode fibers. 

Adjacent areas: The project leveraged knowledge of state-of-the-art technologies, currently used in the design of high-speed optical interconnects based on multimode optical fibers in data centers, and applied it to avionics. The central topics of the project, i.e., M-ary PAM and direct detection in conjunction with digital signal processing, esp. using artificial neural networks for the equalization of fiber transmission effects, are important for short-haul optical communications in general.

Broader impacts: The main themes of the project (avionics, optical fibers) were appealing to a large number of MSU students. This NSF funding was mainly used to train multiple undergraduate and early graduate students in communications theory and optical communications. With regard to underrepresented minorities in science, there was participation of two women and one Native American student. It is worth mentioning that two REU  students joined the project for the summers of 2017 and 2018. One of them came back to MSU to obtain an MS degree in optics. Thus, the project contributed to the development of a diverse, competitive STEM workforce in telecommunications in Montana.
